facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises the question whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds  shortly termed Bonds  issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of companypensation payable on the basis of their rights under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U.P. Act 1 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, have to be accepted by the appropriate authorities in payment of the agricultural income-tax due from them.

facts.text: Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds were issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of compensation under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 (U.P. Act 1 of 1951).

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds  shortly termed Bonds  issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of companypensation payable on the basis of their rights under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U.P. Act 1 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act,

facts.text: The respondent is an ex-Zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the appeal, in brief, are that the respondent, an ex-Zamindar, was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year 1360 F. companyresponding to 1952-53,

facts.text: The respondent was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year 1360 F. corresponding to 1952-53, on the basis of agricultural income in previous year 1359 F. corresponding to 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the appeal, in brief, are that the respondent, an ex-Zamindar, was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year 1360 F. companyresponding to 1952-53, on the basis of the agricultural income accruing in the previous year 1359 F. companyresponding to 1951-52.

facts.text: The respondent did not pay the assessed tax and was assessed to a penalty, resulting in Rs. 868 due for tax plus penalty.

anchor.surface_text: He did number pay the assessed tax and was further assessed to a penalty. In the result, Rs. 868 were to be paid by him for tax plus penalty.

facts.text: The respondent's writ petition contending that he was not liable to pay tax was dismissed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents writ petition companytending that he was number liable to pay tax was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Agricultural income-tax authorities took proceedings for realisation of the amount due from the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the agricultural income-tax authorities took out proceedings for the realisation of the amount due from him.

facts.text: On July 24, 1956, the respondent presented an application to the Agricultural Income-tax Assessing Officer, Allahabad, depositing bonds of Rs. 850 and Rs. 18 in cash, praying acceptance in payment of tax dues.

anchor.surface_text: On July 24, 1956, the respondent presented an application to the Agricultural Income-tax Assessing Officer, Allhabad, stating that he had numberready cash to pay the dues that he was therefore depositing bonds of the value of Rs. 850 and Rs. 18 in cash and praying that the bonds be accepted in payment of tax dues.

facts.text: The application on July 24, 1956 was rejected by the Assessing Officer stating no rule for acceptance of bonds and they be returned.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by an order stating that there was numberrule for the acceptance of those bonds and that they be returned to the applicant.

facts.text: On August 1, 1956, the respondent made a similar application to the Collector complaining that the Assessing Officer had no valid reason to refuse the bonds as they were negotiable instruments.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1956, the respondent made a similar application to the Collector companyplaining that the Assessing Officer had numbervalid reason to refuse to take the bonds when the bonds were negotiable instruments.

facts.text: The application to the Collector on August 1, 1956 was rejected on a report of the Assessing Officer that bonds were not accepted in settlement of agricultural income-tax dues, not negotiable, no provision in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also rejected on a report of the Assessing Officer that the bonds were number accepted in the settlement of agricultural income-tax dues that they were number negotiable and that there was numberprovision in the Act for their acceptance.

facts.text: The respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court of Allahabad praying for certiorari quashing orders of Assessing Officer and Collector, mandamus directing acceptance of bonds or deduction from rehabilitation grant, and prohibition from coercive measures.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent presented a writ petition to the High Court of Allhabad praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Assessing Officer and the Collector, Allhabad, for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing them to accept the bonds in lieu of the tax dues and, in any case, to deduct the amount from rehabilitation grant due to the petitioner and for the issue of a writ of prohibition directing the opposite parties from adopting companyrcive measures for the realisation of the tax due from the petitioner.

facts.text: Naib-Tehsildar Agricultural Income-tax Officer, Allahabad filed counter-affidavit on behalf of the State stating assessment year commencing July 1, 1952 on income from July 1, 1951, tax payable in four installments, penalty of Rs. 43 for each default.

anchor.surface_text: The companynter-affidavit filed by the Naib-Tehsildar Agricultural Income- tax Officer, Allhabad, on behalf of the State, stated that the respondent was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year companymencing from July 1, 1952, on the income derived in the previous year companymencing from July 1, 1951, that the tax had to be paid in four installments and in default of payment a penalty of Rs. 43 was imposed for each default in payment of the four installments

facts.text: High Court quashed the order of the Collector dated August 24, 1956 and directed him to decide the respondent's application dated August 1, 1956 afresh in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore quashed the order of the Collector dated August 24, 1956, and directed him to decide the respondents application afresh in accordance with law as indicated above.

facts.text: The High Court order was dated April 8, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and appealed against the order of the High Court dated April 8, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from the Supreme Court and appealed against the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained special leave from this companyrt and appealed against the order of the High Court dated April 8, 1960.

facts.text: Section 6(d) of the Act was amended by section 3 of U.P. Act XVI of 1953 with retrospective effect from July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: An amendment was made in this clause  d  by section 3 of U.P. Act XVI of 1953, with retrospective effect from July 1, 1952, and the relevant portion of the provision after amendment reads thus

facts.text: Rule 8A was added to the rules by Notification No. 3266/I-A-1056-1954 dated August 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8A was added to the rules by Notification No. 3266/I-A-1056-1954, dated August 17, 1954,

facts.text: In Collector of Sultanpur v. Raja Jagdish Prasad Singh, this court held that section 6(d) applies to arrears of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360 F. on income during 1359 F. and rule 8-A is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this companyrt in Collector of Sultanpur v. Raja Jagdish Prasad Singh that the provisions of section 6 d  of the Act would apply to arrears on account of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360 F. on the basis of agricultural income during the year 1359 F. and that the provisions of rule 8-A are mandatory.

facts.text: Section 68 of the Act provides that compensation shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 68 of the Act provides that the companypensation under the Act shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as may be prescribed.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court order and restored the Collector order dated August 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Collector dated August 24, 1956.

This appeal, by special leave, raises the question whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds  shortly termed Bonds  issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of companypensation payable on the basis of their rights under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U.P. Act 1 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, have to be accepted by the appropriate authorities in payment of the agricultural income-tax due from them.

Thereafter, the respondent presented a writ petition to the High Court of Allhabad praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Assessing Officer and the Collector, Allhabad, for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing them to accept the bonds in lieu of the tax dues and, in any case, to deduct the amount from rehabilitation grant due to the petitioner and for the issue of a writ of prohibition directing the opposite parties from adopting companyrcive measures for the realisation of the tax due from the petitioner.

Without prejudice to the right of the State Government to recover the dues mentioned below such other means, as may be open to it under law  1  all arrears of land revenue in respect of the estates which have vested in the State Government as a result of the numberification under section 4 of the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950,  Act 1 of 1951 , and of tax on agricultural income assessed under the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948,  U.P. Act III of 1949 , due from an intermediary for any period to the date of vesting shall be realised  a  in the case of an intermediary who was assessed to land revenue of Rs. 10,000 or more from the amount of interim companypensation due to him, and  b  in the case of an intermediary who was assessed to a land revenue of less than Rs. 10,000 per annum by deduction from the amount of companypensation payable to him.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63 as it then stood provided that the bonds would be issued in specified denominations and would bear interest at the specified rate on the principal that had become payable calculated from the date of vesting. Rule 64 provided that interest together with the principal of a bond would be paid in equated annual installments except for the last, as described in Appendix IV during the period of 40 years beginning from the date of vesting, provided that any bond might be redeemed at an earlier date at the option of the Government. Rule 65 provided that the installments due on a bond from the date of its enforcement would be payable on presentation from and after July 1st next after the delivery of the bond to the intermediary.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises the question whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds  shortly termed Bonds  issued by the U.P. issues.text: whether section 6(d) of the Act or rule 8-A provides that bonds must or can be accepted in payment of agricultural income-tax

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the above provisions that neither section 6 d  nor rule 8-A provide that bonds must or can be accepted in payment of tax on agricultural income.

holdings.text: neither section 6(d) nor rule 8-A provide that bonds must or can be accepted in payment of tax on agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the above provisions that neither section 6 d  nor rule 8-A provide that bonds must or can be accepted in payment of tax on agricultural income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions of s6(d) and r8A allow deduction from compensation payable under Chapter III but make no mention of accepting bonds issued thereunder

holdings.text: provisions of section 6(d) of the Act apply to arrears of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360 F. on the basis of agricultural income during 1359 F. and provisions of rule 8-A are mandatory

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this court in Collector of Sultanpur v. Raja Jagdish Prasad Singh that the provisions of section 6 d  of the Act would apply to arrears on account of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360 F. on the basis of agricultural income during the year 1359 F. and that the provisions of rule 8-A are mandatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedent from this Court in Collector of Sultanpur v. Raja Jagdish Prasad Singh confirming applicability and mandatory nature

holdings.text: delivery of compensation bonds constitutes payment of compensation such that compensation is no longer payable thereafter

anchor.surface_text: Section 68 of the Act provides that the compensation under the Act shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as may be prescribed. It is clear therefore that the delivery of bonds to the intermediary is in payment of the compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s68 expressly provides for payment in bonds; rules 62-65 confirm bonds are payment mechanism with encashment schedule post-delivery

holdings.text: bonds are not legal tender and there is no obligation on Government or anyone to accept them in payment of dues

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the bonds are negotiable does not make them legal tender and does not make it obligatory on anyone, including Government, to accept them in payment of any dues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Negotiability permits transfer but does not confer legal tender status requiring obligatory acceptance

holdings.text: Collector was not in error in refusing to accept the delivered bonds in payment of agricultural income-tax arrears as no provision requires or permits it and bonds were not cashable
holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of s6(d), r8A, s68, rules 62-65 confirming no acceptance provision post-delivery and bonds not legal tender

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Collector dated August 24, 1956.

It has been held by this court in Collector of Sultanpur v. Raja Jagdish Prasad Singh that the provisions of section 6 d  of the Act would apply to arrears on account of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360 F. on the basis of agricultural income during the year 1359 F. and that the provisions of rule 8-A are mandatory.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Collector dated August 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Section 68 of the Act provides that the compensation under the Act shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as may be prescribed. It is clear therefore that the delivery of bonds to the intermediary is in payment of the compensation.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Collector dated August 24, 1956.
